title: Quiz 7: Childhood Airborne Infections
description: Comprehensive quiz on common childhood airborne diseases: Measles, Whooping Cough, Mumps, and Chickenpox.

questions.question: Which of the following are part of the '3 Cs' diagnostic criteria for Measles? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Cough, Coryza, and Conjunctivitis are the hallmark early signs of measles.
questions.hint: Think of the respiratory and eye signs.

questions.question: What is the name of the characteristic white spots found inside the mouth of a measles patient?
questions.explanation: Koplik's spots are a pathognomonic sign of measles, usually appearing 24-48 hours before the skin rash.

questions.question: Which vitamin supplement is administered as a single dose (200,000 IU) to speed up recovery and prevent complications in measles patients?
questions.explanation: Vitamin A is critical for reducing morbidity and mortality in measles cases.
questions.hint: It is essential for eye and mucosal health.

questions.question: Arrange the typical appearance and spread of the Measles rash in the correct sequence:
questions.explanation: The measles rash 'matches' down the body, starting from the face and neck on day 1.
questions.hint: It moves from head to toe.

questions.question: Match the Whooping Cough (Pertussis) stage with its description:
questions.explanation: Catarrhal is the early stage; Paroxysmal is the hallmark stage; Convalescent is the recovery phase.
questions.hint: The 'whoop' occurs in the middle stage.

questions.question: Young babies under 3 months old with whooping cough typically show the characteristic 'whoop' during paroxysms.
questions.explanation: Young babies often do NOT whoop, making diagnosis difficult and dangerous in this age group.

questions.question: Why is the first dose of the whooping cough (DPT/Pentavalent) vaccine given as early as 6 weeks of age?

options.text: Because babies are born with no immunity to it
Because the vaccine takes 1 year to work

questions.explanation: Babies inherit little or no passive immunity to pertussis from the mother, leaving them highly vulnerable.

questions.question: Which complication of Mumps is most common in post-pubertal males and can lead to infertility?
questions.explanation: Orchitis is the inflammation of the testes, a frequent complication in adult males.

questions.question: Which virus causes Chickenpox and can later reappear as Herpes Zoster (Shingles)?
questions.explanation: Varicella-Zoster Virus causes primary chickenpox and remains dormant in nerve ganglia.
questions.hint: Use the abbreviation or full name.

questions.question: Review the clinical finding in the image. Which complication of measles is likely developing?

richContent.content:
Clinical Case

A child with measles develops nasal flaring, rapid breathing, and chest in-drawing.

questions.explanation: Nasal flaring and rapid respiration (respiratory distress) are signs of secondary pneumonia, a common measles killer.
